column2: CHAPTER THIRTY SEVEN.

column2: A MAN MISSING.
column3: A MAN MISSING.

column2: The breakfast bell of Casa del Corvo had sounded its second and last summons--preceded by a still earlier signal from a horn, intended to call in the stragglers from remote parts of the plantation.
column3: The breakfast bell of Casa del Corvo had sounded its second and last summons-preceded by a still earlier signal from a horn, intended to call in the stragglers from remote parts of the plantation.

column2: The "field hands" labouring near had collected around the "quarter;" and in groups, squatted upon the grass, or seated upon stray logs, were discussing their diet--by no means spare--of "hog and hominy" corn-bread and "corn-coffee," with a jocosity that proclaimed a keen relish of these, their ordinary comestibles.
column3: The "field hands" labouring near had collected around the "quarter;" and in groups, squatted upon the grass, or seated upon stray logs, were discussing their diet-by no means spare-of "hog and hominy" corn bread and "corn coffee," with a jocosity that proclaimed a keen relish of these, their ordinary comestibles.

column2: The planter's family assembled in the _sala_ were about to begin breakfast, when it was discovered that one of its members was missing.
column3: The planter's family assembled in the underscore sala underscore were about to begin breakfast, when it was discovered that one of its members was missing.

column2: Henry was the absent one.

column2: Only the conjecture: that he would shortly make his appearance.

column2: As several minutes passed without his coming in, the planter quietly observed that it was rather strange of Henry to be behind time, and wonder where he could be.
column3: As several minutes passed without his coming in, the planter quietly observed that it was rather strange of Henry to be behind time, and wonder where he could be.

column2: The breakfast of the South-western American is usually a well appointed meal.
column3: The breakfast of the south-western American is usually a well appointed meal.

column2: It is eaten at a fixed hour, and _table-d'hote_ fashion--all the members of the family meeting at the table.
column3: It is eaten at a fixed hour, and underscore table d'hote underscore fashion-all the members of the family meeting at the table.

column2: This habit is exacted by a sort of necessity, arising out of the nature of some of the viands peculiar to the country; many of which, as "Virginia biscuit," "buckwheat cakes," and "waffles," are only relished coming fresh from, the fire: so that the hour when breakfast is being eaten in the dining-room, is that in which the cook is broiling her skin in the kitchen.
column3: This habit is exacted by a sort of necessity, arising out of the nature of some of the viands peculiar to the country; many of which, as "Virginia biscuit," "buckwheat cakes," and "waffles," are only relished coming fresh from, the fire: so that the hour when breakfast is being eaten in the dining room, is that in which the cook is broiling her skin in the kitchen.

column2: As the laggard, or late riser, may have to put up with cold biscuit, and no waffles or buckwheat cakes, there are few such on a Southern plantation.
column3: As the laggard, or late riser, may have to put up with cold biscuit, and no waffles or buckwheat cakes, there are few such on a Southern plantation.

column2: By this time the impression conveyed by Pluto's speech--much more by his manner--notwithstanding its ambiguity, had become sufficiently alarming; and not only the planter himself, but his daughter and nephew, hastily forsaking their seats, and preceded by the sable coachman, made their way to the outside gate of the hacienda.

column2: A sight was there awaiting them, calculated to inspire all three with the most terrible apprehensions.
column3: A sight was there awaiting them, calculated to inspire all three with the most terrible apprehensions.

column2: A negro man--one of the field slaves of the plantation--stood holding a horse, that was saddled and bridled.
column3: A negro man-one of the field slaves of the plantation-stood holding a horse, that was saddled and bridled.

column2: The animal wet with the dews of the night, and having been evidently uncared for in any stable, was snorting and stamping the ground, as if but lately escaped from some scene of excitement, in which he had been compelled to take part.
column3: The animal wet with the dews of the night, and having been evidently uncared for in any stable, was snorting and stamping the ground, as if but lately escaped from some scene of excitement, in which he had been compelled to take part.

column2: He was speckled with a colour darker than that of the dewdrops--darker than his own coat of bay-brown.
column3: He was speckled with a colour darker than that of the dewdrops-darker than his own coat of bay brown.

column2: The spots scattered over his shoulders--the streaks that ran parallel with the downward direction of his limbs, the blotches showing conspicuously on the saddle-flaps, were all of the colour of coagulated blood.
column3: The spots scattered over his shoulders-the streaks that ran parallel with the downward direction of his limbs, the blotches showing conspicuously on the saddle flaps, were all of the colour of coagulated blood.

column2: Blood had caused them--spots, streaks, and blotches!
column3: Blood had caused them-spots, streaks, and blotches!

column3: Whence came that horse?
